repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Agricultural Support Services,
            and Agricultural Research Management Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This audit downgrades the Implementation
            Completion Report's (ICR) assessment of the
            Agricultural Research Management Project (ARMP) to
            moderately unsatisfactory project outcomes, to an unlikely
            sustainability, and with an unsatisfactory Bank performance,
            though concurs with the ICR on modest institutional
            development impacts, and satisfactory Borrower performance
            ratings. Similarly, the audit downgrades the Agricultural
            Support Services Project (ASSP) ICR's ratings, to
            moderately satisfactory project outcomes, and considers
            sustainability as non-evaluable, while concurs with a modest
            institutional development impact, and satisfactory
            performances by the Bank, and Borrower. The lessons, largely
            consistent with findings on research, and extension in other
            countries, suggest the diagnosis of constraints emerging
            during project preparation, should lead to a set of reforms
            identifying the minimum for an effective project, clearly
            articulated, within the evolving Bank management
            documentation. In addition, the adoption of new unified
            national extension approaches, should be based on evaluated
            cost-effectiveness data, though it is important to maintain
            experimentation with alternative approaches to further
            pursue cost-effectiveness. While cutting research costs by
            institutional rationalization (i.e., closing of stations) is
            politically difficult, it is seldom addressed by neither the
            Bank, nor the Borrower, yet should be pursued. Therefore, a
            thorough analysis of project financial sustainability should
            be considered at appraisal time, rather than focusing mainly
            on funding during implementation. Other lessons address the
            need to focus on procurement issues based on intensive early
            supervision, and, introduction of computerized management
            systems, should be matched to the level of computer skills,
            and technical support capacity.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: a) Institutional
            reform of this kind of projects can only be achieved when
            there is a commitment to change by the key stakeholders and
            when there is a formal policy statement and implementation
            strategy. b) Innovative components such as Hortex and the
            homestead improvement programs can only succeed when the
            officials in charge are committed to the proposed
            objectives. c) For a project like this, which contains
            innovative components, very careful and intensive
            supervision is essential. d) This project's
            achievements in policy and institutional reform benefited
            from the services of consultants to assist in developing
            strategies and addressing specific technical and managerial
            issues. e) In this project, the shared experiences during
            the early years of the project in attempting to implement
            the initially agreed reforms and a successful pilot program
            under the project helped to create "ownership" for
            the further reforms introduced following the mid-term
            review. f) In-service training is very beneficial for staff
            at all levels within a national extension service, and the
            most effective training is done at the field level. g) When
            individuals are to pay for equipment themselves, procurement
            requirements should permit buyer's choice subject to
            appropriate limitations.

docna.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Agricultural Support Services
            Project : Credit 2233 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Bangladesh - Agricultural Support
            Services Project : Credit 2233 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary project objective will be to
            improve the impact of agricultural support services as a
            means to raising the standard of living in the farming
            community as a whole.  The needs of women involved in
            agriculture will be specifically addressed.  Subsidiary
            objectives are to: (a) make the technology transfer process
            more responsive to farmer needs; (b) improve the outreach
            capability of the extension service; (c) encourage the full
            participation of private sector seed companies in the supply
            of both food and cash crop seeds; and (d) remove restrictive
            seed regulations so as to provide farmer access to a
            complete range of imported improved crop varieties. Through
            a pilot component the project also aims at promoting
            agro-business opportunities to increase the production
            options for farming enterprises.  At the same time the
            project will support the compatible objective of improving
            the cost-effectiveness of public sector services.  These
            objectives will be achieved through:  (a) a program of
            on-farm demonstrations and farmer field days; (b)
            farmer-information media campaigns; (c) special Upazilla
            initiatives in technology development and transfer; (d)
            upgrading training; (e) expansion of the breeder seed
            operations and regulatory reform to improve seed industry
            efficiency; (f) technical assistance and institutional
            development; and (g) a pilot component for the development
            of horticultural export production among small farmers.
